journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Arthroscopic Single-Row Modified Mason-Allen Repair Versus Double-Row Suture Bridge Reconstruction for Supraspinatus Tendon Tears
title-group.subtitle: A Matched-Pair Analysis

article-meta.aff: *Center for Musculoskeletal Surgery, Charité-Universitätsmedizin Berlin, Campus Virchow, Berlin, Germany
†Department of Radiology, Charité-Universitätsmedizin Berlin, Campus Virchow, Berlin, Germany
Investigation performed at Center for Musculoskeletal Surgery, Charité-Universitätsmedizin Berlin, Campus Virchow, Berlin, Germany

author-notes.corresp: ‡Markus Scheibel, MD, Prof., Center for Musculoskeletal Surgery, Campus-Virchow, Charité-Universitätsmedizin Berlin, Augustenburger Platz 1, 13353 Berlin, Germany (e-mail: markus.scheibel@charite.de).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Arthroscopic double-row fixation of supraspinatus tendon tears compared with single-row techniques is still a matter of debate.

sec.title: Hypothesis:
sec.p: Arthroscopic double-row rotator cuff repair using the suture bridge technique provides better clinical results and lower retear rates than does single-row repair using a modified Mason-Allen stitch technique.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Cohort study; Level of evidence 3.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Forty patients underwent either an arthroscopic single-row modified Mason-Allen stitch (SR) (n = 20; mean age ± SD, 61.5 ± 7.4 y) or a modified suture bridge double-row repair (DR) (n = 20; age, 61.2 ± 7.5 y). The anteroposterior extension was classified as Bateman I in 10% and Bateman II in 90% of patients in the SR group and as Bateman II in 80% and Bateman III in 20% of patients in the DR group. Patients were matched for sex and age. The subjective shoulder value (SSV), Constant-Murley score (CS), and Western Ontario Rotator Cuff Index (WORC) were used for clinical follow-up. Furthermore, MRI scans were conducted for analysis of tendon integrity, muscle atrophy, and fatty infiltration via semiquantitative signal intensity analysis. In addition, re-defect patterns were evaluated.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The mean follow-up time in the SR group was 16.8 ± 4.6 months. The mean SSV was 91.0% ± 8.8%, mean CS was 82.2 ± 8.1 (contralateral side, 88.8 ± 5.3), and mean WORC score was 96.5% ± 3.2%. The mean follow-up time in the DR group was 23.4 ± 2.9 months, with patients achieving scores of 92.9% ± 9.6% for the SSV, 77.0 ± 8.6 for the CS (contralateral side, 76.7 ± 17.1), and 90.7% ± 12.6% for the WORC (P > .05). No significant differences were detected in the clinical outcome between groups. Tendon integrity was as follows. Type 1, none in either group; type 2, 4 SR and 5 DR; type 3, 9 SR and 10 DR; type 4, 3 SR and 3 DR; and type 5, 3 SR and 2 DR. The failure rate was 31.6% (n = 6) in the SR group and 25% (n = 5) in the DR group (P > .05). No significant differences were obtained for muscular atrophy or fatty degeneration (SR group, 0.94 ± 0.16; DR group, 1.15 ± 0.5) (P > .05). Re-defects revealed lateral cuff failure in 83.3% of SR patients in contrast to patients treated with DR techniques. The re-defect pattern was medial cuff failure in 80% of the patients.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: The clinical results after modified Mason-Allen single-row versus double-mattress suture bridge technique did not demonstrate significant differences in a matched patient cohort. Concerning the failure mode, single- and double-row techniques seem to demonstrate different re-defect patterns.

body.p: Several techniques for arthroscopic repair of rotator cuff defects have been introduced over the past few years. Besides established single-row repairs, double-row techniques have gained increasing interest because of superior biomechanical results in comparison with single-row repairs, such as enhanced footprint coverage, better construct stability with higher ultimate tensile load, and decreased gap formation.§ However, recently published clinical studies have not identified a clearly superior technique.50 Several investigators have reported similar clinical results for single-row and double-row repairs.‖ Although a few studies have been published that suggest better tendon integrity and lower retear rates for double-row repairs, these results were not reflected in clinical outcome.12,52,56

Many of the cited studies compared simple and relatively weak single-row techniques such as simple or mattress stitches with standard double-row repairs.10,27,46 There are few studies available comparing a strong, self-locking single-row repair with the suture bridge double-row technique as originally introduced by Park et al.47 The present clinical study compares the arthroscopic modified Mason-Allen stitch as described by Scheibel and Habermeyer, which is a complex single-row technique that provides biomechanical results superior to those provided by simple or mattress stitches, with the complex modified suture bridge double-row technique, with regard to clinical and radiologic outcome.37,47,54
The hypothesis of this study is that the biomechanical superiority of double-row repairs leads to better clinical and radiologic outcome compared with single-row repairs.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: In 2005, the first series of patients received a reconstruction of the supraspinatus tendon that used a single-row repair with the modified Mason-Allen stitch technique (Figure 1).54 In 2006, we switched to a modified suture bridge double-row technique for the second series of patients, where both limbs from each of the 2 sutures perforated the tendon medially to establish horizontal mattress stitches (Figure 1).47,51 Fifty-four patients were treated with double-row technique and 22 with single-row modified Mason-Allen fixation. All surgeries were performed by a single surgeon.

caption.p: (A) Schematic drawing of single-row repair using the modified Mason-Allen stitch and (B) the modified double-row suture bridge repair. Reprinted from Arthroscopy: (A) Scheibel and Habermeyer54 ©2003; (B) Pauly et al51 ©2010. With permission from Elsevier.

sec.p: The main inclusion criterion for the study group was a repairable superior rotator cuff tear of the supraspinatus tendon classified grade II and III according to Bateman4 (Table 1). Patients with concomitant injuries such as biceps tears, subacromial impingement, or acromioclavicular joint arthritis were included. Exclusion criteria were shoulder stiffness, osteoarthritis, traumatic tears, and revision cases.

tr.th: Extension of Complete Cuff Tear Anterior-Posteriora

tr.td: Proximal stump close to the bony insertion
Proximal stump at level of apex humeri
Proximal stump at or beyond level of glenoid
Global cuff tear with little or no cuff left

sec.p: From this pool of individuals, 40 patients were matched for gender and age (within 3 y). The matching procedure was blinded to the outcome, guaranteeing the sorting of patients according to the matching parameters without bias in their outcomes.

After the matching procedure and inclusion and exclusion process were complete, this study included 20 patients in each group (10 women and 30 men; mean age, 61.2 ± 7.3 y). Patients in group 1 underwent surgery using a single-row repair technique, and the patients in group 2 were treated with the double-row technique (Table 2).

tr.th: Group 1: Single- Row Repair With Modified Mason-Allen Stitch
Group 2: Double- Row Repair Suture Bridge

sec.title: Surgical Technique
sec.p: The surgical procedures were performed with the patient in beach-chair position under general anesthesia. Preoperative intravenous antibiotics were administered. Routine portals were used. A diagnostic arthroscopy via a standard posterior portal was performed. A tenodesis or tenotomy of the long head of the biceps was conducted if necessary. Subsequently, the rotator cuff tendon was debrided, and the greater tuberosity was gently abraded with a bur to allow bleeding from the greater tuberosity footprint. The single-row repairs were performed with the arthroscopic modified Mason-Allen stitch (Figure 1), using 5.5-mm Bio-Corkscrew anchors (Arthrex, Naples, Florida) double loaded with FiberWire suture (Arthrex).54 The anchor placement was close to the osteochondral intersection. The placement close to the glenohumeral cartilage leads to a medialized reconstruction. To begin with, the mattress stitch was performed by passing both free limbs of the first suture intra-articularly through the tendon into the subacromial space using the Scorpion Needle (Arthrex). The sutures were placed approximately 10 mm from the tendon edge and approximately 10 mm next to each other. Before the mattress suture was tied, a single stitch was performed with a free limb of the second suture passed between the previous suture and approximately 1 to 2 mm more medially. The horizontal mattress suture was tied first so that the vertical single stitch could then be tied on top of it. For knot security, a Duncan loop followed by 3 to 4 half-hitches of alternating throws and posts was used (Figure 2).30

caption.p: Single-row repair using the arthroscopic modified Mason-Allen stitch.

sec.p: The double-row repairs were performed with the modified double-row suture bridge technique. In contrast to the technique originally reported by Park et al,47 both sutures of each anchor are passed through the tendon in a double-mattress fashion (Figure 1).51

For the medial row, two 5.5-mm Bio-Corkscrew FT (Arthrex) anchors double loaded with FiberWire suture were used. The anchor placement was close to the osteochondral intersection. The anchors were placed as far anteriorly and posteriorly as possible to maximize the pressurized contact area. Both limbs from each of the 2 sutures were passed through the tendon by use of the Scorpion Needle (Arthrex) at the musculotendinous junction, resulting in 4 mattress stitches medially.51 After the medial row was tied as described earlier, the suture limbs were used to create suture bridges across the tendon.47,51 To establish the lateral row, two 3.5-mm PushLock anchors (Arthrex) were fully inserted at an angle perpendicular to the cortical surface of the humerus (Figure 3).

sec.title: Rehabilitation
sec.p: The postoperative rehabilitation was identical for both groups. The affected upper extremity was placed in an abduction sling (Ultrasling II, DJO Global Inc, Vista, California) for 6 weeks with only passive mobilization. During the first 3 weeks postoperatively, passive range of motion up to 60° of forward flexion and 60° of abduction was administered. In this period, external rotation as well as internal rotation was restricted to 0° for the first 6 weeks. From the fourth week, passive range of motion was extended up to 90° of forward flexion and 90° of abduction. After 6 weeks postoperatively, free passive mobility was gradually improved. Active mobilization was encouraged as well as specific training of the rotator cuff and the deltoid muscle.

sec.title: Clinical and Radiologic Evaluation
sec.p: At the time of follow-up, a complete physical examination of both shoulders was performed. All patients were evaluated using the subjective shoulder value (SSV), the Constant-Murley shoulder scoring system (CS), and the Western Ontario Rotator Cuff Index (WORC).18,25,28 In addition, all patients underwent MRI with a 1.5-T system (Signa Twin Speed, General Electric, Milwaukee, Wisconsin). The shoulder was placed in a shoulder coil with the arm in neutral position. The following sequences were applied in transaxial, parasagittal (perpendicular to the scapula), and paracoronal (parallel to the scapula) slice orientation: localizer sequence (all 3 directions of space), T1-weighted spin echo (SE) sequence (parasagittal), T1-weighted SE sequence (paracoronal), proton density (PD)-weighted SE sequence (paracoronal), and PD-weighted SE sequence (transaxial).
For data analysis, the workstation Advantage Windows (General Electric, Milwaukee, Wisconsin) and the software program Functool 2.5.24 (General Electric) were used.

Tendon integrity and retear rate were evaluated by analyzing the paracoronal PD-weighted SE sequence using the classification of Sugaya et al.56 This classification system grades the postoperative cuff integrity into 5 categories. Types 1 and 2 reveal sufficient tendon thickness, with partial high intensity in type 2. A thinned tendon without discontinuity is type 3. Type 4 integrity is a retear displaying a discontinuity on up to 2 slides in MRI. A retear seen on more than 2 slides reveals a integrity failure type 5. Muscular atrophy according to Thomazeau et al58 was detected on the parasagittal T1-weighted SE sequence. Furthermore, the fatty infiltration of the supraspinatus muscle was evaluated using a semiquantitative signal intensity analysis. On the parasagittal T1-weighted images, the most lateral image was used with the scapular spine in contact with the coracoid process (the so-called Y-shaped position). After definition of elliptical regions of interest of identical size (25 mm2), the signal intensity was measured with the integrated software. Five elliptical regions of interest in the supraspinatus (SSP) muscle and, for comparison, 5 elliptical regions of interest in the teres minor (TM) muscle were located to calculate the signal-to-signal ratio (SSR): SSR = TM/SSP.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: All analyses were performed with SPSS 16.0 software (SPSS Inc, Chicago, Illinois). To evaluate differences between the groups in the shoulder scores, a nonparametric Mann-Whitney U test and a 1-way analysis of variance were used. Differences in muscular atrophy and tendon integrity were evaluated using a chi-square test. An a priori power analysis with an effect size of 0.934 was calculated; furthermore, post hoc power analysis based on tendon integrity was performed and revealed a power greater than 0.85 with α = .05 in a total sample size of 38 patients. The level of significance was set at P < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Data are expressed as means ± standard deviations. The mean follow-up time of all patients was 23.3 ± 12.7 months. There were 10 women and 30 men divided into 2 groups matched regarding age and sex. The final clinical evaluation was carried out in 40 patients with a mean age of 61.4 ± 7.2 years (range, 48-78 y). Radiographic analysis could be performed in 19 patients in group 1. One patient experienced claustrophobia and the protocol had to be aborted, resulting in incomplete MRI sequences for that patient.

sec.title: Group 1: Single-Row Modified Mason-Allen Stitch Repair
sec.p: The mean age of patients in group 1 (5 women, 15 men) was 61.5 ± 7.4 years.

sec.title: Intraoperative Findings
sec.p: The initial tear size in this group was Bateman I in 10% and Bateman II in 90%.4 The tendon retraction according to Patte49 was grade 0 in 45% and grade I in 55%. Among the patients of this group, 40% had symptomatic acromioclavicular joint arthritis.

sec.title: Postoperative Follow-up
sec.p: The mean follow-up time was 16.8 ± 4.6 months. Patients with single-row surgery had a mean SSV of 91.0% ± 8.8%. The mean CS score was 82.2 ± 8.1 (contralateral side, 88.8 ± 5.3 points), whereas the WORC score was 96.5% ± 3.2%. The postoperative tendon integrity was evaluated as type 2 in 4 patients, type 3 in 9 patients, type 4 in 3 patients, and type 5 in 3 patients. Thus, the overall retear rate was 31.6% (n = 6). Eight patients had muscle atrophy grade I, 9 patients had grade II, and 2 patients had grade III. The semiquantitative signal intensity analysis resulted in 0.94 ± 0.16. When we evaluated the patterns of re-defects for these 6 patients, we noted that 5 patients had a lateral cuff failure and the sixth patient had a medial cuff failure.

sec.title: Group 2: Double-Row Modified Suture Bridge Repair
sec.p: Patients in group 2 (5 women, 15 men) had a mean age of 61.2 years (SD, ±7.5 y).

sec.title: Intraoperative Findings
sec.p: The initial tear size was Bateman 0 in 0%, Bateman II in 80%, and Bateman III in 20% of the patients in group 2.4 The tendon retraction preoperatively was grade 0 in 5%, grade I in 75%, and grade II in 20% of these patients.49

sec.title: Postoperative Follow-up
sec.p: The mean follow-up was 23.4 ± 2.9 months. This group scored 92.9% ± 9.6% for the SSV, 77.0 ± 8.6 points (contralateral side, 76.7 ± 17.1 points) for the CS, and 90.7% ± 12.6% for the WORC. Here, the tendon integrity according to Sugaya et al56 was type 2 in 5 patients, type 3 in 10 patients, type 4 in 3 patients, and type 5 in 2 patients. Thus, the overall re-tear rate was 25% (n = 5). Eight patients had a muscle atrophy grade I, 9 patients had grade II, and 2 patients had grade III according to Thomazeau et al.58 The semiquantitative signal intensity analysis resulted in 1.15 ± 0.5.

sec.title: Comparison of the Groups
sec.p: The surgical time was 112.2 ± 23.5 minutes for group 1 and 109.1 ± 21.3 minutes for group 2, revealing no statistical difference (P = .59).

There were no significant differences between patients in groups 1 and 2 in the overall CS (82.1 vs 77.0 points, respectively; P > .05). There were no significant differences between groups 1 and 2 in the CS for pain (14.2 vs 13.2 for groups 1 and 2, respectively), activities of daily living (18.7 vs 17.9), range of motion (38.1 vs 37.2), and strength (11.0 vs 9.3; P > .05). Neither results for the SSV (91.0% vs 92.9%) nor for the WORC (96.5% vs 90.7%) differed significantly (P > .05) (Table 3).

caption.p: Outcome in the Shoulder Scores of the 2 Groupsa

tr.th: Group 1: Single-Row Repair With Modified Mason-Allen Stitch

sec.p: The duration until free range of motion could be achieved was recorded in our outpatient department, and the health record documented 6.9 ± 3.0 months in group 1 and 6.4 ± 3.1 months in group 2. This difference was not statistically significant (P = .31), even though 1 patient in group 2 developed a postoperative frozen shoulder that spontaneously resolved after 15 months.

Furthermore, the radiologic evaluation did not show any statistically significant differences between the 2 groups (Table 4). Tendon integrity was evaluated for single-row versus double-row techniques, respectively, as follows: type 1, n = 0 versus 0; type 2, n = 4 versus 5; type 3, n = 9 versus 10; type 4, n = 3 versus 3; and type 5, n = 3 versus 2. Thus, the integrity failure was 31.6% (n = 6) for the patients of group 1 (single row) and 25% (n = 5) for the patients in group 2 (double row). No significant differences (P = .276) were detected with regard to muscular atrophy or fatty degeneration (single row, 0.94 ± 0.16; double row, 1.15 ± 0.5).

tr.th: Group 1: Single- Row Repair With Modified Mason-Allen Stitch
Group 2: Double- Row Repair Suture Bridge

fn.label: a
fn.p: According to Sugaya et al.56 Values are numbers of patients. Significance, P = .05.

sec.p: Finally, when we compared the clinical outcome of patients with intact tendons (Sugaya type I through III) versus patients with retears (Sugaya type IV and V), the CS values revealed a significant difference between patients with intact tendon and patients with retears (81.3 vs 74.3; P = .045) (Table 5). Separated into its subitems, the CS only showed significant differences in “strength” (11.3 vs 7.1; P = .03). Patients with intact tendon had significantly better results in the strength category. Taking into account the pattern of recurrent defects, we found lateral cuff failure in 5 of 6 patients with retears in group 1, whereas in group 2 cases of re-tear predominantly displayed a medial cuff failure.19,59

caption.p: Constant Score: Intact Tendon Versus Failed Repairsa

tr.td: Mean score, intact tendon vs repair

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values are expressed in points as mean ± standard deviation.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study evaluates clinical and radiographic results after single- and double-row repair of supraspinatus tendon tears. Our hypothesis that the biomechanical superiority of double-row repairs leads to better clinical and radiologic outcome compared with single-row repairs could not be confirmed.

In terms of clinical outcome, no significant differences could be detected in this study. The subjective shoulder scores such as SSV and WORC as well as the CS showed no significant differences between the 2 groups. Although the single-row group reached more points for every item of the CS score—pain, activities of daily life, range of motion, and strength—a superiority of one group over the other could not be detected.

Although double-row techniques offer high initial fixation strength, minimal gap formation, and sufficient mechanical stability, the radiographic results did not reveal significant differences between the 2 groups, which other studies have demonstrated as well.¶

The optimal arthroscopic repair of supraspinatus tendon tears is still a matter of debate. Many authors have developed novel techniques for arthroscopic reconstruction of the rotator cuff to optimize the biomechanical features of the construct or to allow “anatomic” reconstruction of the tendon insertion area.#

Still, the problem of achieving an anatomic reconstruction is not yet solved. In cases of degenerative cuff tears, the surgeon has to treat a substantial defect that entails loss of tendon tissue. Additionally, the fibers remaining at the footprint have to be debrided for reconstruction. A retraction of the musculotendinous complex with atrophy and fatty degeneration of the muscle appears26 followed by further tendinous shortening in chronic situations.41,42 To cover the entire footprint, increased lateralization is necessary. Parts are attached to the tendon insertion that might have never been in contact with the footprint, which results in an overtensioning of the whole musculotendinous unit. With the single-row technique, the reconstructed tendon is inserted in a medial fashion, reducing the strain to the tissue. Still, given these facts, any reconstruction technique cannot claim to be anatomic except perhaps in posttraumatic cases.

Several studies have reported comparisons of different single- and double-row reconstruction techniques. In a prospective cohort study, Charousset et al12 evaluated the clinical and radiographic outcome of single-row and double-row rotator cuff repair. Although computed tomography arthrography performed 6 months after surgery showed significantly better tendon healing in the double-row group and more retears in the single-row group (22.5% vs 40%), clinical follow-up at 24 months did not show any significant difference between groups in clinical results. These data confirm several studies that showed no differences in clinical results between the single-row repair and the double-row technique.2,10,21,27 Interestingly, often a simple stitch configuration, which results in a quite weak biomechanical construction, is compared with highly stable double-row techniques. Modified suture configurations for single-row techniques reveal improved biomechanical properties: Biomechanical studies point out that the number of sutures passing the tendon might be a fundamental factor determining initial stability.3,35,36,39

Using a primary stable single-row technique, Lichtenberg et al33 reported on the clinical and radiographic results of 32 patients treated with modified Mason-Allen suture repair; the investigation demonstrated significantly improved CS scores and a defect recurrence rate of 25%.

To potentially increase the healing rate, the transosseous equivalent or suture bridge technique as introduced by Park et al47,48 showed significant improvement in the 2-dimensionally pressurized contact area when compared with regular double-row techniques. Concerning clinical and radiologic results, Frank et al22 reported an intact reconstruction site of 89% after a follow-up of 12 months. A higher recurrent insufficiency rate of 28.9% was reported after a prolonged follow-up by Voigt et al61; that study still achieved good clinical results, represented by a mean CS score of 94%.

Comparing the primary biomechanical, stable single-row method (massive cuff stitch) with the double-row suture bridge technique, Pennington et al52 were among the first authors evaluating 2 groups of patients in a prospective, nonrandomized assessment. There were no differences concerning the clinical results but the investigators found an unexpected, lower retear rate for the single-row technique (20.5% vs 30.8%; P = .017). The reason for this mentioned by the authors was the inhomogeneity of the tear size between the 2 groups. A more homogeneous subset of patients with tears between 2.5 and 3.5 cm showed a significantly improved healing rate for the double-row repair (P < .03). When we account for the tear size, the double-row technique seems to be superior in reconstruction of large to massive rotator cuff tears (tear size >3 cm).43,46,52 Nevertheless, one has to be careful interpreting subgroup analysis given that only a few patients are compared, which possibly leads to a bias.

Recurrent defects are one of the most common complications of arthroscopic rotator cuff repairs.8,23 With regard to the study hypothesis and based on the current results, the assumption that improved tendon healing occurs with a broader double-row attachment must be seen under a differentiated view.34 The rate of integrity failure in this study was 30% for the single-row group and 25% for the double-row group (P > .05), which are comparable to findings reported in the literature.7,17,22 To evaluate possible reasons for re-defects or diminished tendon integrity, we accounted for the respective pattern of recurrent defects: In 80% (4/5 cases) of the recurrent defects in the double-row group, a medial cuff failure was observed as described previously.59,62 In contrast, the single-row group predominantly displayed lateral cuff failures (in 5/6 cases).19 A similar disposition of these 2 re-rupture configurations was described by Cho et al14 for single- and double-row repair. The authors found a lateral failure in 73.7% of cases after single-row repair and an inverse amount of 74.1% of medial cuff failures after suture bridge repair. The high number of medial cuff failures in the double-row group might present a new and true re-rupture. Different kinds of factors might be suitable to explain this phenomenon. Since the medial perforations are placed close to the musculotendinous junction, which displays a weaker structural area, and the musculotendinous unit is lateralized for reconstruction, the medial row represents the load-bearing area. As demonstrated by several authors performing biomechanical cadaveric testing, the failure appeared next to the medial row of the reconstruction.5,51 Possibly strangulation with subsequent reduction of blood supply might contribute to medial cuff failure, since Christoforetti et al16 described a significant decline after the lateral row was placed. Furthermore, the use of braided suture materials leads to increased abrasion properties compared with monofilament sutures.31 A further factor was described when a weak zone is created using retrograde suture passing instruments, causing greater holes through the rotator cuff.15,59 To avoid increased damage during suture passage, a Scorpion Needle, as an antegrade suture passer, was used in all patients undergoing single- and double-row repair.

Medial cuff failure is relevant because it displays a new kind of complication with a structural defect close to the musculotendinous junction. The high incidence of medial cuff failures demonstrates the necessity for prevention. Since the medial row presents the load-bearing part and given that strangulation of the tendon might occur, a possible modification of the suture bridge technique might be necessary, leaving the medial horizontal row untied.60

If revision surgery is indicated in cases of medial cuff failure, lateralization may not always be possible. In some cases it is necessary to place side-to-side sutures and afterward try to repair the remaining tissue at the footprint. Although patients in the present study with inferior tendon integrity or failed cuff repairs (Sugaya IV and V) had worse results in the subitem “strength” of the CS, no significant differences in subjective shoulder scores such as the SSV and WORC were evident. Fortunately, no revision surgery was required. Several studies have revealed that pain, function, and retear are not dependent solely on initial biomechanical strength and footprint coverage of the reinserted tendon, because postoperatively tendon integrity does not always correlate with clinical outcome.1,22,32,61

Nevertheless, adequate function and integrity are desirable goals of a rotator cuff repair. During the past years, reconstruction techniques have been developed in attempts to fulfill the criteria for an adequate repair postulated by Gerber et al.24 The criteria include a minimal gap formation, a high initial fixation strength, less tissue damage, and the maintenance of mechanical stability until solid tendon-to-bone healing has taken place. Despite achieving the characteristics, these techniques reveal a relatively high recurrent insufficiency.13,21,27,53,61

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: This study has several advantages and disadvantages. The patients were matched according to their gender and age, resulting in a quite homogeneous collection. To achieve further homogeneity, only patients with a Bateman II and III rupture configuration were selected and treated with 2 or 4 anchors depending on the reconstruction technique by a single surgeon. Nevertheless, a relatively small number of patients were selected in each group. The power analysis revealed that for SSV, a total sample size of 740 patients is necessary with a significance level α = .05 and a power >0.85. For CS and WORC scores, a total sample size of 54 and 46 patients is needed, respectively.
Noncontrast MRI was used to evaluate the repair integrity. To increase expressiveness and to sufficiently detect smaller retears, magnetic resonance arthrography would have been desirable.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Clinical results after a modified Mason-Allen single-row versus double-row mattress suture bridge technique did not demonstrate significant differences in a matched patient cohort. Furthermore, radiographic examination did not provide significant differences with regard to re-tear rate, muscular atrophy, and fatty infiltration between both approaches. Concerning the failure mode, single- and double-row techniques seem to demonstrate different patterns: Medial cuff failure at the musculotendinous junction seems to be a pattern after suture bridge reconstruction. These repair configurations should be applied with caution since functional outcome and retear rate do not differentiate and a new kind of retear pattern occurs that is difficult and challenging to revise.

fn.p: One or more of the authors has declared the following potential conflict of interest or source of funding: Dr Scheibel is a consultant for Arthrex Inc.
